title: Visualizing Heterogeneous Protein Conformations with Multi-Tilt Nanoparticle-Aided Cryo-Electron Microscopy Sampling
content: Studying heterogeneous conformations of small proteins in solution is essential for understanding their role in biological processes, but achieving this using traditional methods are challenging [1-3]. To address this challenge, we developed a Multi-Tilt Nanoparticle-Aided Cryo-Electron Microscopy Sampling (MT-NACS) technique [3]. This technique enables direct measurement of the three-dimensional distance distribution between two gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) attached to a protein by capturing cryo-electron microscopy images of AuNP-labeled proteins from multiple tilt angles (Fig. 1). To demonstrate the capabilities of MT-NACS, we selected calmodulin (CaM) as a model system and measured the structural changes of CaM under various sample conditions. We observed structural changes in CaM before (apo-CaM) and after Ca2+ binding (holo-CaM) at different salt concentrations (Fig. 2A-F). Additionally, for the first time, we used MT-NACS to measure the structural changes in CaM before and after its binding with the amyloid-beta peptide (Fig. 2G-L). MT-NACS offers a new approach for understanding the conformational changes of small proteins, as detailed in the published paper [3].
